pullRequest.body:
Add various congruency lemmas for `Cardinal.mk`.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

The statement of `mk_sigma_congr_subtype` is slightly different than `mk_pi_congr_subtype` (#16795) because sigmas don't have the `Σ i ∈ S` notation. I went with what I thought is the most likely way to talk about sigmas of subtypes, what do you think?

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [efe881c37f](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16824/commits/efe881c37f41c9fdd90207ab3581e3d76bfeb728)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ mk_pi_congr`
`+ mk_pi_congr'`
`+ mk_pi_congrRight`
`+ mk_pi_congrRight_prop`
`+ mk_pi_congr_lift`
`+ mk_pi_congr_prop`
`+ mk_psigma_congrRight`
`+ mk_psigma_congrRight_prop`
`+ mk_sigma_congr`
`+ mk_sigma_congr'`
`+ mk_sigma_congrRight`
`+ mk_sigma_congr_lift`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

I created the `Sigma` ones. I think `mk_sigma_congr` and `mk_sigma_congr'` are both needed: `mk_sigma_congr` is the case where the indexing types are in the same universe, and `mk_sigma_congr'` allows different universes so it requires the output universe to be higher than them both. If this is alright I'll do the same with `Pi`.
(since you were going to add the `pi` versions here too)

@eric-wieser said:
> My weak objection here is that if the link to `Equiv` is considered an implementation detail, then we end up needing a `congr` lemma for every functorial Equiv in mathlib, which doesn't scale particularly well.

What do you mean by a functorial Equiv?

I'm not saying we shouldn't ever employ equivalences in arguments about cardinality, we have [`Equiv.cardinal_eq`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Cardinal/Basic.html#Equiv.cardinal_eq) which is often useful. But rather, stuff like `#α + #β = #(α ⊕ β)` or (more relevantly to this PR) `#Σ (α i) = sum fun i ↦ #(α i)` isn't often very useful, since in many cases, there's much stronger results available like `#α + #β = max (#α) (#β)`. That's why I think it's fine to have these congruence lemmas.

> What do you mean by a functorial Equiv?

`Equiv.piCongr`, `Equiv.sigmaCongr`, `Equiv.setCongr`, `Equiv.finsetCongr`, `Equiv.sumCongr`, etc.

But most of these don't need congruence lemmas! If `#α₁ = #α₂` and `#β₁ = #β₂` then `#α₁ + #β₁ = #α₂ + #β₂` is just two `rw`s. If `s = t` then `#s = #t`, again by rewriting. These congruence lemmas can't be proven by just rewriting like that.

LGTM

bors d=@eric-wieser

:v: eric-wieser can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11228858247/job/31213459344)
bors r-
Canceled.

Can you merge master, fix the build, and send it back to bors?
bors d+

:v: YnirPaz can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11304018271/job/31441837043)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11304018271/job/31441836878)
bors r+
Let's wait for a resolution to my comments on #16795 before merging this one; but thanks for making things consistent either way.
bors r+
`Σ i, Σ' (_ : i ∈ S), f i` would be another option here, if you wanted to match the `pi` version.

Thi is a special case of the more general
```suggestion
theorem mk_pi_congr_subtype {ι : Type u} {f g : ι → Type v} {p : ι → Prop}
    (h : ∀ i, p i → #(f i) = #(g i)) : #(Π i, p i → f i) = #(Π i, p i → g i) := mk_congr <|
```
(set `p := fun i => i ∈ S` to see this).

Can you change the others too?

I don't think this lemma is a good one, it can be proved in terms of the one above and something that you're missing:
```lean
theorem mk_pi_congrRight_prop {ι : Prop} {f g : ι → Type v} (h : ∀ i, #(f i) = #(g i)) :
    #(Π i, f i) = #(Π i, g i) :=
  mk_congr <| Equiv.piCongr (.refl _) fun i ↦ Classical.choice <| Cardinal.eq.mp (h i)

theorem mk_pi_congrRight_subtype {ι : Type u} {f g : ι → Type v} {p : ι → Prop}
    (h : ∀ i, p i → #(f i) = #(g i)) : #(Π i, p i → f i) = #(Π i, p i → g i) := by
  refine mk_pi_congrRight fun i => ?_
  refine mk_pi_congrRight_prop fun hi => ?_
  apply h _ hi
```

I'm not sure I understand. I renamed things, now there are `mk_pi_congr`, `mk_pi_congr'`, `mk_pi_congrRight` and `mk_pi_congrRight_prop` (renamed from `_subtype`). What you wrote as `mk_pi_congrRight_prop` is just `mk_pi_congrRight`, and your `mk_pi_congrRight_subtype` is `mk_pi_congrRight_prop`.
I also don't follow your comment @eric-wieser, could you elaborate?
The difference is `ι : Prop` vs `ι : Type*`. `Sort*` doesn't work, so you need the two theorems separately.

This is not the right statement; "subtypes" of sigmas are spelt as one of:
```lean
#check Σ x : Nat, Σ' h : x > 0, Fin x
#check Σ x : Nat, (x > 0) ×' Fin x
#check Σ x : Nat, PLift (x > 0) × Fin x
```
This is a bit like the common binder confusion with `Exists`:
```lean
∃ x : { x // x > 0}, x.val^2 = 4
∃ x, x > 0 ∧ x^2 = 4 -- equivalent to the above
∃ x, x > 0 → x^2 = 4 -- meaningless, you can use ` x=0`.
```
This looks pretty hard to apply; perhaps it should be stated with `lift`s in the equalities?

I just wanted `mk_pi_congr` and `mk_pi_congr'` to cover all the cases where the outputs are in the same universe. We can also make lift versions, but maybe in another PR? This already inflated quite a bit from the single sigma congr  lemma I wanted it for originally haha.

Anyways if `mk_pi_congr'` is too obscure I don't mind removing it.
@vihdzp, I think you've worked with `lift` more than anyone; what's your preference here?

The usual design pattern is to first prove a version with general universes using `lift`, and to then use that to prove a more convenient version where the universes match. In this case, the lift version would look like this:
```lean 4
theorem mk_pi_congr_lift {ι : Type u} {ι' : Type v} {f : ι → Type w} {g : ι' → Type x} 
    (e : ι ≃ ι') (h : ∀ i, lift.{x} #(f i) = lift.{w} #(g (e i))) :
    lift.{max v x} #(Π i, f i) = lift.{max u w} #(Π i, g i) :=
  Cardinal.lift_mk_eq'.2 ⟨Equiv.piCongr e fun i ↦ Classical.choice <| Cardinal.lift_mk_eq'.1 (h i)⟩
```
Presumably that should be called `lift_mk_pi_congr`?

The convention seems to be to suffix `lift` lemmas like this. See e.g. [`Cardinal.mk_image_le_lift`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Cardinal/Basic.html#Cardinal.mk_image_le_lift), [`Cardinal.mk_range_eq_lift`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Cardinal/Basic.html#Cardinal.mk_range_eq_lift), [`Cardinal.mk_iUnion_le_lift`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/SetTheory/Cardinal/Basic.html#Cardinal.mk_iUnion_le_lift), etc.
@vihdzp Thanks for the lift version! I added it along with a sigma version. I don't see a way to use it to prove the non lift versions more easily here so I kept them the same.

I pushed my change here; I claim that the last lemma isn't very useful, since:
* It does not handle the csae when `f` and `g` are dependent functions
* It mentions `subtype` in the name even though it does not use subtypes
* It follows trivially by combining the other lemmas, which also works for general quantifiers.
Maybe `umax` should be in the name, since this is about `max` in `u`niverses? Is there any precedent for `umax` in names like this?

There are only 7 theorems with `umax` in the name and they all talk directly about universes (theorems about `lift` and `Cardinal.univ`). Mostly primes are used for these kinds of stuff in the set theory library.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(SetTheory/Cardinal/Basic): congruency theorems for cardinalities of sigmas
